para.paratext: In Georgia, the results of polygraph tests, whether favorable or unfavorable to the accused, are not admissible in evidence, as they are not considered reliable.[1] However, the parties may consent to the admissibility with an advance written or oral agreement or stipulation.[2]
In Parfenuk v. State,[3] the Court of Appeals reversed where the trial court permitted the state to introduce evidence of a lie detector test where no agreement by the parties had been reached.

In State v. Chambers,[4] the defendant was convicted of statutory rape. Prior to trial, both he and his alleged victim agreed to take polygraph tests and the defendant stipulated with the state that the results of both would be admissible. At trial, the examiner testified that the polygraph results showed the defendant was lying in denying the crime and the victim was truthful in accusing him. The Georgia Supreme Court upheld the admission of the test results and found that the evidence was enough to corroborate the accusation of the rape victim, but, alone, would not be enough support a conviction. “When the only evidence of guilt is defendant's performance on a lie detector test, a conviction may not stand.”[5]
Later, the court held that polygraph evidence is sufficient to corroborate the testimony of an accomplice.[6]
The trial judge may not require or compel the district attorney to give a defendant or witness a polygraph test.[7]

In Willis v. State,[8] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the district attorney need not state his reasons for declining to stipulate to admissibility of a polygraph test result and in Robertson v. State[9] declined to entertain defendant's argument that the state violated his due process rights by refusing to stipulate to the admissibility of the results of a polygraph test because the issue had already been considered and rejected by the court in Willis v. State.[10]

Georgia courts have rejected the argument that there can be an “implied” stipulation by the state. In McGraw v. State,[11] the Georgia Court of Appeals stated that Georgia law clearly requires an express stipulation by the parties before polygraph evidence may be admitted at trial.

Also, a defendant cannot rely on statements by the examiner before the polygraph test was administered “that the evidence could and would be used against him” as an implied stipulation of admissibility by the state.[12]
Nor would the state's stipulation of another person's test in another case affect admissibility of an exam in the defendant's case.[13]

However, if otherwise relevant and admissible, statements made by the examiner and defendant during the course of the test will not be excluded simply because they were made before, during, or after a lie detector test.[14] Such evidence must be presented without any reference to the test, if there is not a prior stipulation as to the admissibility of the polygraph.[15]

The Court of Appeals has held that a defendant's stipulation as to the admissibility of polygraph results is unambiguous and expressly given where the caption on the form stated “State of Georgia v. Montavius Thomas” but where no court was specified, no case number appeared, and no charges were pending against the defendant at the time the polygraph test was administered.[16]

Evidence of the defendant's agreement or refusal to take a polygraph test is never admissible.[17] Thus, the defendant may not properly admit evidence that he “offered” to take a polygraph test.[18] “In Georgia, the law of evidence in criminal trials is that the results of polygraph examinations are probative and admissible upon express stipulation, but that all other evidence concerning polygraphs is nonprobative, irrelevant, and inadmissible.”[19] Moreover, evidence that a defendant initially agreed to take a polygraph, but later refused to take the test is inadmissible.[20]
The same is true if the results of a polygraph test are “inconclusive.”[21] Such evidence is without probative value even if the parties stipulate as to the admissibility of the results.[22]

However, if one test is “inconclusive” and a second test is “deceptive,” “the ‘inconclusive’ test is admissible for impeachment and as tending to show the polygraph is not infallible, and for the purpose of raising a reasonable doubt of defendant's guilt.”[23] Thus, if the state offers relevant, admissible polygraph evidence, the defendant also has the right to offer his own expert testimony regarding the results of the test.[24] “No one would doubt that ‘the results of a lie detector test’ are subject to ‘varying opinion.’”[25]

The Court of Appeals has upheld the use of polygraph testing as part of a defendant's probation. And while the court maintains that probation may not be terminated due to the actual answers provided to specific questions, a general failure to complete mandated sex offender treatment, including required polygraph testing, was considered a violation of probation despite the appellant's assertion that mandated and ongoing polygraph testing amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.[26]

The Court of Appeals permitted evidence that a party had offered to take a lie detector test where the other party questioned the efficiency and adequacy of an investigator, and the opposing party argued that the evidence regarding the polygraph was necessary to rebut the inference that the investigator did not do a thorough job, and to explain the investigator's conduct. The court noted that the jury was not presented with evidence of when the test took place, or the results of the test.[27]
Parfenuk v. State, 338 Ga. App. 95, 789 S.E.2d 332 (2016).
See Dein v. Mossman, 244 Ga. 866, 262 S.E.2d 83 (1979).
A written stipulation is the “best practice.” Davis v. State, 172 Ga. App. 701, 324 S.E.2d 551 (1984).

See also Blount v. State, 172 Ga. App. 120, 322 S.E.2d 323, 21 Ed. Law Rep. 386 (1984) (oral stipulation); Walker v. State, 264 Ga. 79, 80, 440 S.E.2d 637 (1994); Moclaire v. State, 215 Ga. App. 360, 451 S.E.2d 68 (1994).
Results of a polygraph test cannot be used for impeachment in the absence of a stipulation. Harrell v. State, 253 Ga. 474, 321 S.E.2d 739 (1984).
State v. Brown, 185 Ga. App. 701, 365 S.E.2d 865 (1988), held that the trial judge properly construed the terms of the stipulation in excluding the results of the test.
Porterfield v. State, 150 Ga. App. 303, 257 S.E.2d 372 (1979), held that, if the results of the polygraph test were inconclusive, they should be excluded.

The court distinguished Porterfield in Lawson v. State, 162 Ga. App. 579, 292 S.E.2d 421 (1982), where the first test was inconclusive and the second test showed deception by the defendant. The trial judge admitted the results of the second test, but excluded the first test. This was error even though there was a stipulation.
Parfenuk v. State, 338 Ga. App. 95, 789 S.E.2d 332 (2016).
State v. Chambers, 240 Ga. 76, 239 S.E.2d 324 (1977); Reynolds v. State, 147 Ga. App. 488, 249 S.E.2d 305 (1978); Williams v. State, 148 Ga. App. 55, 250 S.E.2d 848 (1978).

Harris v. State, 168 Ga. App. 458, 309 S.E.2d 431 (1983), held that the limiting charge in Chambers should be given whenever polygraph results are admitted and the examiners written report should not go out with the jury.
In Williams v. State, 251 Ga. 749, 312 S.E.2d 40 (1983), an improper reference to the fact that a witness had taken a lie detector test could be cured by the court and did not require a mistrial.

See also Thornton v. State, 279 Ga. 676, 620 S.E.2d 356 (2005) (“[W]hile accomplice testimony alone is insufficient to support a conviction for a felony … the testimony concerning the results of appellant's polygraph examination is sufficient corroboration of an accomplice's testimony to authorize a guilty verdict.”).
Benson v. State, 150 Ga. App. 569, 258 S.E.2d 156 (1979).
See Willis v. State, 249 Ga. 261, 290 S.E.2d 87 (1982).
Robertson v. State, 268 Ga. 772, 493 S.E.2d 697 (1997).
Robertson v. State, 268 Ga. 772, 493 S.E.2d 697 (1997).

The issue was also considered by the Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit in a case from Georgia. In Jones v. Weldon, 690 F.2d 835 (11th Cir. 1982), the court held that a written statement from the prosecutor of his reasons for failing to enter into a stipulation for admission of the results of a polygraph test was not constitutionally required.
McGraw v. State, 199 Ga. App. 389, 405 S.E.2d 53 (1991).
McGraw v. State, 199 Ga. App. 389, 393, 405 S.E.2d 53 (1991).
McGraw v. State, 199 Ga. App. 389, 405 S.E.2d 53 (1991).

Drane v. State, 265 Ga. 255, 455 S.E.2d 27 (1995), relying on Stack v. State, 234 Ga. 19, 25, 214 S.E.2d 514, 88 A.L.R.3d 216 (1975), and Williams v. State, 144 Ga. App. 130, 135, 240 S.E.2d 890 (1977). In Drane, the Georgia Supreme Court upheld the admission of testimony about defendants statements made to the examiner before the polygraph began; in so doing, the court noted that the defendant had been read his Miranda warning and had signed a waiver of rights form and that the trial court ordered that there could be no comment referring to the polygraph examination itself. Drane v. State, 265 Ga. 255, 455 S.E.2d 27 (1995). Accord, State v. Rogers, 223 Ga. App. 525, 479 S.E.2d 377 (1996). Drane v. State, supra, also expressly overruled Johnson v. State, 208 Ga. App. 87, 88, 429 S.E.2d 690 (1993), which held that statements by defendant made immediately before and after he was connected to polygraph machine, as part of his unstipulated polygraph examination, were not admissible against him.
Thomas v. State, 330 Ga. App. 67, 766 S.E.2d 527 (2014).
See Johnson v. State, 272 Ga. App. 385, 612 S.E.2d 518 (2005).
Lemons v. State, 172 Ga. App. 193, 322 S.E.2d 521 (1984).
Johnson v. State, 272 Ga. App. 385, 386, 612 S.E.2d 518 (2005) (quoting Brown v. State, 175 Ga. App. 246, 249, 333 S.E.2d 124 (1985)).
State v. Parks, 2019 WL 2573887 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
Sisson v. State, 181 Ga. App. 784, 353 S.E.2d 836 (1987).
Porterfield v. State, 150 Ga. App. 303, 304, 257 S.E.2d 372 (1979).
Sisson v. State, 181 Ga. App. 784, 787, 353 S.E.2d 836 (1987) (citing Lawson v. State, 162 Ga. App. 579, 292 S.E.2d 421 (1982)).
Sisson v. State, 181 Ga. App. 784, 353 S.E.2d 836 (1987).
Hilley v. State, 344 Ga. App. 58, 806 S.E.2d 280 (2017).
Heard v. Payne, 828 S.E.2d 657 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
